Award.AwardTitle: SNM: A Versatile Microplasma-based Patterning Technology for Large-Scale, High Throughput Nanomanufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the development of a microplasma-based, direct-write fabrication tool to produce sub-100 nm metallic and metal oxide device structures on rigid and flexible substrates. The patterned structures will be formed by selective electrochemical reduction of metal ions dispersed in polymeric films by plasma electrons. Different metals will be explored including Ag, Au, Pt, Cu, and Ti. To control the pattern dimension, a durable nanostencil masking technology will be incorporated into the process. Simulations and experiments will be performed to explore and elucidate the relationship between the stencil geometry and charged fluid transport that ultimately determines the pattern transfer and scaling. Concurrently, nanolayered polymer substrates with moisture barrier properties suitable for durable flexible electronics will be developed. The two process technologies will be integrated on a roll-to-roll line to demonstrate process compatibility and scalability. The resulting metallic nanostructures will be evaluated for such properties as electrical conductivity, adhesion, density, surface roughness, pattern fidelity, and responses to applied strains. Accelerated lifetime testing will be performed to assess the viability of the structures in commercial applications.

If successful, this research will result in a highly versatile, low-cost, high-throughput method for the fabrication of nanoscale structures and functional devices on flexible substrates. The microplasma-based patterning process is operated near room temperature, making it compatible with a wide variety of substrates ranging from silicon to polymers, and at atmospheric pressure, making it readily scalable to continuous production systems. The technology has the potential to complement state-of-the-art, direct-write nanofabrication systems currently used in silicon CMOS electronics, as well as creating new opportunities to fabricate nanoscale devices for flexible electronics and sensors. Additionally, integration of the microplasma tool with nanolayered polymer substrates could enable the development of flexible electronic systems for moisture latent environments including implantable medical microsystems.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the development of plasma-based, direct-write patterning techniques and novel, multilayered polymer substrates for the manufacturing of flexible electronic devices. The effort to develop additive patterning processes centered on the application of atmospheric and low pressure plasmas to fabricate conductive metal structures. Patterning techniques were developed specifically for large-area, polymeric substrates, including those compatible with roll-to-roll processing. The processes were developed for a wide range of metals used in micro and nanoelectronics, some of which have yet to be used in an additive microfabrication process of any kind. This project concurrently developed nanolayered polymer substrates that exhibit gas and moisture barrier characteristics not currently available in conventional homogeneous polymer materials.

This project resulted in the successful development of three distinct plasma-based approaches to direct-write patterning. The first approach involves the use of atmospheric pressure-based microplasmas to fabricate electrically-conductive metal structures in the near surface region of a metal cation-containing polymer. By incorporating a PDMS elastomer as a supporting substrate and prestraining prior to plasma exposure, the fabricated metallic features were found to exhibit negligible change in resistivity for uniaxial strains up to 35%. We found that the high stretchability of the conductive regions is related to uniform strain delocalization which is made possible by how the metallized layer is formed, growing from within the polymer matrix rather than by deposition on its surface, to create a quasi-monolithic structure without a well-defined metal–polymer interfacial boundary.

The second approach involves the development of atmospheric pressure microplasma-based sputtering for direct-write deposition of metal structures. The process capitalizes on a physical vapor that is generated within a small capillary by plasma-generated Ar ions that bombard a small diameter metal wire. Integration with an x-y-z stage enables patterning without the need for masks. The process is performed entirely at atmospheric pressure, thereby addressing the most significant equipment-related limitation associated with conventional magnetron sputtering and thermal evaporation, and requires no substrate heating, allowing deposition on temperature-sensitive substrates such as liquid crystal polymer, PDMS and paper.

The third approach involves the development of a new method for inkjet printing based on particle-free inks formulated from inorganic metal salts and their subsequent low-temperature conversion to metallic structures by a non-equilibrium, low pressure Ar plasma. This single, general method is demonstrated for a library of metals including gold, silver, copper, palladium, platinum, lead, bismuth, and tin. These metals were printed and plasma activated at substrate temperatures between 77°C and 138°C. The resistivities of the inkjet-printed and converted metals were measured to be between 2X and 10X of the respective bulk metals. Uniquely, the metal films were found to exhibit a very large surface area because of the plasma-initiated nucleation and growth process, making the printing technique attractive for sensor applications. To demonstrate the utility of the printing technique, a Bi-based trace Pb ion sensor, a Au-based amyloid-β sensor, a Au-based strain gauge, and a Ag-based thermistor were fabricated as representative chemical, biological, mechanical, and thermal sensors.

Regarding the development of novel substrates for flexible electronics, this project focused on the manufacturing of nanolayered polymer composites from rheologically-mismatched components by employing the Extensional Mixing Element (EME) approach as a means of improving the degree of mixing efficiency in the compounding steps used in the multilayering process.  The effort here focused specifically on improving the gas and moisture barrier characteristics in order to make flexible electronics more durable to environmental exposure. Greatest success was observed in the ethylene vinyl alcohol (EVOH), tin phosphate glass (Pglass) material system. Best results from a performance and processing perspective were realized for PGlass with a Tg of 97°C and a loading of 10 wt%. The multilayered composite exhibited longer relaxation times at all strain rates than neat EVOH. The mechanical properties of the composite were different from a normal polymer/inorganic filler system in that the composite exhibited higher ductility and flexibility due to competition of hydrogen bonding between EVOH chains-PGlass and EVOH chains-EVOH-chains. Undrawn composite films showed higher permeability than undrawn neat EVOH. However, upon drawing, the EVOH/ PGlass composite film displayed much lower values of permeability by more than one order of magnitude than neat EVOH and undrawn EVOH/PGlass composite films. This was a result of highly elongated PGlass particles, which was calculated to have aspect ratios between 40 and 100. 

A total 17 students with experience levels that range from high school through PhD participated in the research activities of this project. Five of these students were supported by REU funding, of which three were from underrepresented groups. The project provided research experiences to four high school students, two of them from underrepresented groups. The cross-disciplinary nature of this project required an integrated approach to project execution, exposing the students to benefits and challenges of team-based research.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/27/2019
Modified by: Christian A Zorman
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project focused on the development of plasma-based, direct-write patterning techniques and novel, multilayered polymer substrates for the manufacturing of flexible electronic devices. The effort to develop additive patterning processes centered on the application of atmospheric and low pressure plasmas to fabricate conductive metal structures. Patterning techniques were developed specifically for large-area, polymeric substrates, including those compatible with roll-to-roll processing. The processes were developed for a wide range of metals used in micro and nanoelectronics, some of which have yet to be used in an additive microfabrication process of any kind. This project concurrently developed nanolayered polymer substrates that exhibit gas and moisture barrier characteristics not currently available in conventional homogeneous polymer materials. This project resulted in the successful development of three distinct plasma-based approaches to direct-write patterning. The first approach involves the use of atmospheric pressure-based microplasmas to fabricate electrically-conductive metal structures in the near surface region of a metal cation-containing polymer. By incorporating a PDMS elastomer as a supporting substrate and prestraining prior to plasma exposure, the fabricated metallic features were found to exhibit negligible change in resistivity for uniaxial strains up to 35%. The second approach involves the development of atmospheric pressure microplasma-based sputtering for direct-write deposition of metal structures. The process capitalizes on a physical vapor that is generated within a small capillary by plasma-generated Ar ions that bombard a small diameter metal wire. Integration with an x-y-z stage enables patterning without the need for masks. The process is performed entirely at atmospheric pressure, thereby addressing the most significant equipment-related limitation associated with conventional magnetron sputtering and thermal evaporation, and requires no substrate heating, allowing deposition on temperature-sensitive substrates such as liquid crystal polymer, PDMS and paper. The third approach involves the development of a new method for inkjet printing based on particle-free inks formulated from inorganic metal salts and their subsequent low-temperature conversion to metallic structures by a non-equilibrium, low pressure Ar plasma. This single, general method is demonstrated for a library of metals including gold, silver, copper, palladium, platinum, lead, bismuth, and tin. Uniquely, the metal films were found to exhibit a very large surface area because of the plasma-initiated nucleation and growth process, making the printing technique attractive for sensor applications. To demonstrate the utility of the printing technique, a Bi-based trace Pb ion sensor, a Au-based amyloid-β sensor, a Au-based strain gauge, and a Ag-based thermistor were fabricated as representative chemical, biological, mechanical, and thermal sensors. Regarding the development of novel substrates for flexible electronics, this project focused on the manufacturing of nanolayered polymer composites from rheologically-mismatched components by employing the Extensional Mixing Element (EME) approach as a means of improving the degree of mixing efficiency in the compounding steps used in the multilayering process. The effort here focused specifically on improving the gas and moisture barrier characteristics in order to make flexible electronics more durable to environmental exposure. Greatest success was observed in the ethylene vinyl alcohol (EVOH), tin phosphate glass (Pglass) material system. Best results from a performance and processing perspective were realized for PGlass with a Tg of 97°C and a loading of 10 wt%. The multilayered composite exhibited longer relaxation times at all strain rates than neat EVOH. The mechanical properties of the composite were different from a normal polymer/inorganic filler system in that the composite exhibited higher ductility and flexibility due to competition of hydrogen bonding between EVOH chains-PGlass and EVOH chains-EVOH-chains. Undrawn composite films showed higher permeability than undrawn neat EVOH. However, upon drawing, the EVOH/ PGlass composite film displayed much lower values of permeability by more than one order of magnitude than neat EVOH and undrawn EVOH/PGlass composite films. This was a result of highly elongated PGlass particles, which was calculated to have aspect ratios between 40 and 100. A total 17 students with experience levels that range from high school through PhD participated in the research activities of this project. Five of these students were supported by REU funding, of which three were from underrepresented groups. The project provided research experiences to four high school students, two of them from underrepresented groups. The cross-disciplinary nature of this project required an integrated approach to project execution, exposing the students to benefits and challenges of team-based research.
